title: Andy Capp’s Fries Get 4/20 Buzz
content:
During the California gold rush, fortunes were made selling picks and shovels instead of actually mining for gold. During the current cannabis boom, as 10 U.S. states and Canada have legalized recreational marijuana, the equivalent may be selling snacks rather than pot.
Conagra Brands is thinking along these lines. The food company, widely admired in the industry for its track record of turning around aging brands, sees opportunity for the Andy Capp’s line of snacks, named after the layabout star of the British comic strip....

title: Disney Shares Surge After Disney+ Streaming-Service Update
content:
Walt Disney Co. shares surged to an all-time high Friday, as investors and analysts cheered the opportunity for Disney+, the newest addition to the company’s suite of streaming services, to win subscribers in an increasingly crowded landscape.
Stock in the California entertainment company rose 12% to $130.06, breaking the previous intraday record set in August of 2015, bringing gains this year to 18%.
On...

title: Once More With Feeling: Fix Your Withholding!
content:
Congratulations American taxpayers, you made it through the first filing season after the largest tax overhaul in a generation. Now do yourself a favor and check your withholding.
For weeks, news articles, message boards, and family dinners have been filled with unhappy taxpayers lamenting tax-refund shortfalls or surprise bills. For many, that’s because they didn’t watch their withholding.
Among...

title: Germany’s Merck to Acquire Versum in $6.56 Billion Cash Deal
content:
Merck KGaA said Friday it reached a deal to buy Versum Materials Inc. for $53 a share in cash, scuttling a merger with Entegris Inc.
Merck valued its purchase of Versum at 5.8 billion euros ($6.56 billion) and said the deal strengthens its position in the semiconductor industry, which is expected to see a boost from growth in the use of artificial intelligence, big data and internet-of-things applications.
Germany’s...

title: Rip-Roaring Chinese Exports Less Than They Appear
content:
To everything there is a season – especially in China.
Friday’s very strong March export figure, up 14% on the year after falling 20% in February, wasn’t exactly a surprise. Much ink was spilled on very weak Chinese exports and industrial profits in February, so expect more on this big export rebound.
Yet all the figures were heavily distorted...

title: Military Faces High Turnover of Top Brass
content:
The Pentagon within the coming months is expected to undergo its most dramatic period of turnover at top military levels under the Trump administration, during which top civilian leaders aren’t serving in a permanent capacity.
At least five of the seven members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff will be replaced this year, including the chairman, vice chairman and heads of the Army, Navy and Marine Corps.
Military...

title: Spring Books: Spring Cleaning
content:
Louise Nevelson could have been a productivity guru for the tech set. The prolific American sculptor woke up at 6 every morning wearing cotton clothing that served as both her pajamas and work uniform. At mealtime, she consumed a can of sardines and a piece of stale bread with a cup of tea—the 20th-century version of Soylent. “I read once that in her old age Isak Dinesen only ate oysters and drank champagne,” Nevelson wrote in her autobiography, “and I thought what an intelligent solution to ridding oneself of meaningless decision-making.”
Perhaps...

title: George Putnam, Born to Influence, Led Investment Firm and Managed Harvard’s Money
content:
His family tree included a general who led troops in the Revolutionary War, a governor of Massachusetts and a president of Harvard University. So a certain amount of leadership was always expected of George Putnam. He delivered it in a quiet fashion.
After serving in World War II and considering a scientific career, he complied with his father’s wishes to join Putnam Investments, the Boston-based fund-management company founded by the elder Mr. Putnam in 1937.
...

title: Taxi App That Drove Uber From China Sees Its Valuation Stall
content:
Not every ride-hailing giant is riding a surge in valuations.
Uber Technologies Inc.’s IPO documents this week provided fresh insights into its Chinese rival Didi Chuxing, another of the world’s most valuable ride-hailing companies, but one that has encountered various setbacks over the past year.
Uber said it owns 15.4% in Beijing-headquartered...

title: ‘Never a Lovely So Real’ Review: A Walk on the Wild Side
content:
Colin Asher’s generally sturdy new biography of Nelson Algren, the third one of the writer to appear, shows in certain penitential asides why it may be the last: If a biographer needs to apologize for the noun “lovely” in his own title (“tame misogyny” when Algren used it, but “offensive” today), it’s doubtful his rugged white-male subject will much longer be considered acceptable posthumous company.
Born in 1909, the son of a car mechanic, Algren grew up in Chicago with an enthusiasm for boxing, baseball, gangsters and writing....

title: Joe Biden Navigates Complaints About Touching as 2020 Spotlight Looms
content:
WASHINGTON—Ally Coll said she had been willing to forgive Joe Biden for making her feel uncomfortable at a fundraiser in Seattle about a decade ago. But his response to allegations from women that he violated their personal space and touched them inappropriately changed her mind.
“I would’ve considered supporting him if his response to these stories would’ve been different,” said the former Democratic aide, who went on to co-found the Purple Campaign, a nonprofit dedicated to fighting workplace sexual harassment. “But in light...

title: Powell Reiterates Fed’s Independence at Democrats’ Retreat
content:
LEESBURG, VA—Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reiterated the independence of the central bank Thursday night in a closed-door meeting with House Democrats and said he wouldn’t comment on President Trump or his potential nominees to the Federal Reserve’s board.
Mr. Powell made clear that he saw his role as apolitical and valued the central bank’s independence, according to lawmakers who watched him speak at the party’s retreat. He was interviewed by Rep. Joyce Beatty (D., Ohio), who leads a House Financial Services Committee...

title: PNC Results Lifted by Loan Growth
content:
Strong loan growth helped fuel a rise in revenue and profits for PNC Financial Services Group Inc. in the first quarter.
Revenue for PNC, one of the country’s largest regional banking companies, rose 4.3% from a year earlier to $4.29 billion. Analysts polled by Refinitiv were expecting $4.27 billion in revenue.
Net interest income rose 4.8%...

title: U.S.-China Trade Pact Takes Aim at Currency Manipulation
content:
WASHINGTON—As part of a prospective deal on trade, the U.S. and China have agreed to measures that American officials say will deter Beijing from currency manipulation by requiring greater disclosure of economic actions, according to current and former officials familiar with the negotiations.
The deal could also include penalties for China if it manipulates its currency to increase exports, which is in violation of international guidelines, these people say.
...

title: U.S. Consumer Sentiment Drops as Tax-Cut Boost Fades
content:
Consumers’ outlook on the U.S. economy worsened in April, as a survey suggested the impact of tax cuts has now run its course for American households.
The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment was 96.9 this month, down from March’s final reading of 98.4. That undershot economists’ expectations for a preliminary reading of 98.0.
The...

title: North Korea Offers Rare Glimpse of Its Financial Picture
content:
SEOUL—North Korea outlined plans to increase government spending on science, technology and infrastructure, despite sanctions that have bruised the cash-strapped regime’s economy.
The spending plan was released at a gathering of North Korea’s rubber-stamp legislature, the Supreme People’s Assembly, where leader Kim Jong Un won re-election to the country’s highest seat of power, state media reported Friday.
The...

title: Across the Universe
content:
Art that depicts the cosmos can tell us how a civilization views itself as well as its surroundings. Beginning April 30, the Getty Center in Los Angeles will examine the medieval view of the universe in “The Wondrous Cosmos in Medieval Manuscripts.” The shimmering, gold-flecked colors of the manuscript illustrations can seem as fresh as when they were painted, yet they offer a reminder of how distant the Middle Ages really are, and how little people then knew about the world they lived in.
Astronomers of the Middle Ages did...

title: JPMorgan Results Beat Expectations on Strength in Consumer Unit
content:
The country’s largest bank, JPMorgan Chase & Co., said a bright economy and strong lending drove it to a record profit in the first quarter.
That gave its stock price a boost, and the wider stock market a lift as well. The S&P 500 climbed 0.7%.
JPMorgan executives said the U.S. consumer is in good shape, pointing to healthy credit-card...

title: Behind Uber’s Slowing Growth: Onslaught of Global Competition Takes a Toll
content:
Uber Technologies Inc. has talked up its expansion into new businesses beyond ride-hailing, from food delivery to long-haul trucking. But it can’t escape the fierce competition.
The ride-hailing giant’s IPO documents made public Thursday show a company besieged by competitors on all fronts, leading to sharp declines in revenue growth just as it readies to market itself to growth-hungry public-market investors.
Faced...

title: Fiction: Morality Plays for the Present Moment
content:
The narrator of James Lasdun’s “Afternoon of a Faun” (Norton, 165 pages, $25.95) offers readers a word of caution on fiction about accusations of sexual assault, this novel’s fraught subject. Because the writer has to decide which character is telling the truth, he gives the appearance of choosing a side in a broader public debate and his story is reduced to “polemic or propaganda.” The lofty literary ideal of negative capability is impossible to achieve.
Or is it? This is the question Mr. Lasdun unravels in his slippery,...

title: JPMorgan and Wells Fargo: Two Roads Diverged
content:
The outlook for U.S. banks is less exciting than the strong earnings figures from JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo suggest.
The two banking giants both reported first-quarter earnings well ahead of analyst expectations Friday. At JPMorgan, net profit rose 5% from a year earlier, while at Wells Fargo it jumped 14%. JPMorgan’s stock climbed 4% in early morning trading, while Wells Fargo was up 2%.
JPMorgan...

title: Score One for the Electronic Bond Traders
content:
When global markets tumbled in December, U.S. corporate bond investors scrambled to sell holdings they feared would drop further. But bank traders weren’t buying, so many fund managers turned to a fast-growing electronic marketplace to reduce their exposures.
Almost one-quarter of all investment-grade corporate bond trades in December were on MarketAxess, the highest monthly market share ever for the digital trading venue. Market share for Trumid Financial LLC, a much smaller electronic corporate bond trading venue, was also...

title: Spring Books: Nature
content:
Are six trees enough to make a grove? If not, then these six books about trees, unfolding their leaves in harmony with the spring, may at least make up a stand or copse or spinney.
“Around the World in 80 Trees” (Laurence King, 240 pages, $24.99), by a former trustee of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, may be the most accessible of these volumes. Like Phileas Fogg, Jonathan Drori circles the globe by setting out from London and heading east. Along the way he offers brief accounts of some of the world’s most unusual or significant...

title: Mysteries: Sensitive, Awkward and Deranged
content:
The eponymous police unit in Alexander McCall Smith’s “The Department of Sensitive Crimes” (Pantheon, 229 pages, $24.95), operating out of Malmö, Sweden, deals with cases involving “complicated investigation”—or, in the words of senior member Ulf Varg, “something outré.”
Mr. McCall Smith’s engaging book (which tackles three oddball mysteries) teeters between comedy and pathos as the squad tussles with bizarre activity. In one investigation, a stall-keeper in a public market is stabbed in the back of the knee by an unseen assailant....

title: Soros-Backed Hedge Fund CJW Shelves Plans for Launch
content:
A deal by Soros Fund Management to invest in a new hedge fund has fallen apart, according to people familiar with the matter.
London trader Chris Wheeler left hedge-fund Citadel LLC and millions in deferred compensation in 2018 to launch CJW Capital Management. That launch was based on the strength of an agreement he had with billionaire investor George Soros’s family office, the people said.
Under...

title: Saudi Arabia Promised Support to Libyan Warlord in Push to Seize Tripoli
content:
Days before Libyan military commander Khalifa Haftar launched an offensive to seize the capital and attempt to unite the divided country under his rule, Saudi Arabia promised tens of millions of dollars to help pay for the operation, according to senior advisers to the Saudi government.
The offer came during a visit to Saudi Arabia that was just one of several meetings Mr. Haftar had with foreign dignitaries in the weeks and days before he began the military campaign on April 4.
...

title: Paris-Roubaix: How ‘Hell’ Became More Chill
content:
TEMPLEUVE-EN-PÉVÈLE, France—The vast majority of racers to enter cycling’s most infernal race have never made it to the finish line.
Over the course of 123 years, they ground to a standstill cursing broken bicycles on cobbled roads in northern France. Or they landed hard in muddy pileups. Or they simply gave up. For Paris-Roubaix, that’s always been kind of the point.
But...

title: China Trade Numbers Raise Red Flags on Embryonic Economic Recovery
content:
BEIJING—China’s trade performance last month raised questions about demand in the global and Chinese economies, as exports rebounded and imports fell at rates steeper than expected.
China’s exports rose 14.2% from a year earlier in March, according to Chinese customs data released Friday. The increase reversed a 20.7% drop in February and the pace was nearly twice that expected by many economists.
Rather...

title: A Once Fast-Growing Chinese Tech Giant Cuts Back
content:
BEIJING—China’s hard-charging e-commerce company JD.com is retrenching, rolling out wide-scale layoffs and closing most offices abroad, people familiar with the matter said, to cut costs to cope with a slowing economy and rising competition.
In recent weeks, employees described the Beijing-based company as beset by unease, with a leaked memo taking aim at underperformers. Some departments have ordered staff members to engage in self-criticism sessions to assess their and others’ performance, employees said, and departures...

title: European Privacy Regulators Find Their Workload Expands Along With Authority
content:
European regulators are struggling to keep up with the big increase in corporate data breach notifications since the European Union privacy law took effect last May.
“There’s been a real concern about the sheer volume of work that is arriving at the regulators’ doorsteps,” said Trevor Hughes, president and chief executive of the nonprofit International Association of Privacy Professionals.
Faced...

title: Price, the Final Frontier: Blue Origin’s Tourist Rocket
content:
What moved me most about Blue Origin’s factory in Kent, Wash., where the New Shepard tourist rocket is built, was the nearness of it all—the realization that, if I don’t fall off a ladder in the next year or so, I will have a chance to soar to the edge of space, 62 miles in altitude, the so-called Karman Line.
Plenty of chances, actually. As Blue Origin execs describe it, New Shepard’s West Texas launch site will operate rather like a skydiving outfit: Clients will show up, suit up, receive some brief training, and blast...

title: China Chops Price for a Much-Criticized ‘Belt and Road’ Project in Malaysia
content:
China slashed by nearly a third its price for building a multibillion-dollar Malaysian railway, salvaging a project seen as crucial to Chinese President Xi Jinping’s program to develop global infrastructure.
The two governments wrangled for months over the project, which critics had lambasted as overpriced. On Friday, Chinese and Malaysian executives in Beijing signed an agreement that cuts the cost of the East Coast Rail Link project to 44 billion ringgit ($10.7 billion) from 65.5 billion ringgit, according to a statement...

title: Beer for Those Seeking Balance
content:
BEER NAMES can be as misleading as they are meaningful. Mild ale, a forgotten British style making waves again, actually packs plenty of flavor.
At only 3 or 4% ABV, these soothing beers are suited to sipping, successively, over the course of an afternoon. Out swirl notes of toffee and cocoa, walnuts and toast, biscuits and coffee.
Hearty...

title: ICC Won’t Launch Formal Investigation in Afghanistan
content:
The International Criminal Court won’t pursue an investigation into alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Afghanistan by combatants including those from the U.S. and its allies, removing a major point of contention with the Trump administration.
President Trump called the decision “a major international victory, not only for these patriots, but for the rule of law.”
A...

title: China’s Auto Sales Fall for Ninth Month
content:
SHANGHAI—China’s auto sales declined for a ninth straight month in March, and a leading industry executive said he can’t predict when a rebound will come.
Chinese vehicle sales in the first quarter of 2019 were down 11.3% year over year to 6.37 million, the government-backed China Association of Automobile Manufacturers said Friday. That decline followed the 12% and 9.6% drops of the previous two quarters, respectively. In March, sales fell 5.3% year over year to 2.52 million.
...

title: ‘The Problem of Democracy’ Review: Cicero & Son; or, a Party of Two
content: In the last week of his life, a small delegation of neighbors called upon John Adams at Peacefield, the ample country house in Quincy, Mass., that its owner had mockingly dubbed Montizello in contrast to the far grander mountaintop dwelling of Thomas Jefferson. His visitors encountered a palsied, toothless, half-blind figure, unable to rise from his favorite armchair to greet them. Yet Adams more than rose to the occasion when invited to supply a toast to be read at the town’s upcoming celebration commemorating 50 years since the Declaration of Independence redefined a patchwork quilt of British colonies as a sovereign...

title: Oil Prices Rise, Fueled by Advancing Stock Markets
content:
• Oil prices rose Friday as a strong day for U.S. stock markets gave commodity markets a boost and allowed crude to close higher on a weekly basis for a sixth consecutive week.
• West Texas Intermediate futures, the U.S. oil benchmark, ended 0.5% higher at $63.89 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. WTI is 41% higher from where it began the year.
•...

title: Five Best: Peter S. Carmichael on Life as a Civil War Soldier
content:
No Freedom Shrieker: The Civil War Letters of Union Soldier Charles Biddlecom Edited by Katherine M. Aldridge (2011)
1As soon as New Yorker Charles Biddlecom joined the Army of the Potomac, he wanted to escape. Drafted in 1863, he shared none of the idealism of the volunteers of 1861. In virtually every letter to his family he complained about politicians, generals and, above all, army life. He told his wife that “I think sometimes if it was not for you and my children I would blow out my brains.” Biddlecom pulled through this...

title: This Proxy Season, It’s Revenge of the Nurdles
content:
If you’re like many of those I’ve introduced the word “nurdle” to in the last week or so, you giggled the first time you heard it.
In the boardrooms of some of America’s largest corporations, though, the nurdle is no laughing matter. As the proxy season dawns, it symbolizes a new front in the thrust-and-parry between investors with social goals and directors with bottom lines.
Nurdles...

title: ‘Game of Thrones’ Madness Is Starting Again. Pity the Non-Watchers.
content:
When the last season of “Game of Thrones” kicks off Sunday night on HBO, millions of fans will tune in for the final chapters of the multiseason saga to discover…what exactly? Something to do with winter? Or dragons?
People who have never watched the prime-time fantasy series that became a cultural tsunami say the last eight years have been a trial. Non-watchers endure ceaseless office chitchat, marital disharmony and speculation about family dynasties and ice zombies. They aren’t really sure what’s been going on, but they’re...

title: U.S. Government Bonds Fall After Chinese Data Beats Expectations
content:
U.S. government-bond prices fell Friday after better-than-expected Chinese economic data helped reduce demand for safer assets.
The yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note settled at 2.560%, compared with 2.502% on Thursday.
Yields, which move in the opposite direction of prices, climbed overnight after new data showed Chinese banks...

title: A Star Was Born. The NBA Wasn’t Ready.
content:
If you had to invent someone who could fit perfectly on any team in today’s NBA, as with most hypothetical scenarios that life presents, you’d want that person to be like Klay Thompson.
The Golden State Warriors guard is a three-time champion and five-time All-Star who is bound for the Hall of Fame one day and could sign a contract this summer worth more than $200 million. He’s silly rich in large part because he’s the archetype of modern basketball. He’s the right size at 6-foot-7 and 215 pounds. He’s interested in playing...

title: Wells Fargo Posts Higher Profit, But Revenue Slides
content:
Wells Fargo & Co.’s interim chief executive said Friday that the bank wouldn’t provide an update about when it expects to emerge from an asset cap imposed by the Federal Reserve.
The Fed took the rare step of restricting the bank’s growth in February 2018, citing risk-management deficiencies. On a call with analysts Friday to discuss the bank’s first-quarter earnings, interim Chief Executive C. Allen Parker said that the bank’s leaders “do not feel it’s appropriate to provide guidance as to the timing of the lifting...

title: ‘The Sakura Obsession’ Review: New Life for a Tree
content: In Western countries, we take the blooming of the cherry blossoms as just another sign of spring, like the budding of the forsythia and azaleas. But in Japan, where the flowering cherry, or sakura, has been cultivated for centuries, the blossom has a much deeper, and at times far darker, significance. In “The Sakura Obsession,” Naoko Abe, a Japanese journalist living in London, grafts two improbable stories onto the same rootstock. One tale is of an English gentleman with little previous experience of gardening, who became a world authority on cherry trees. The other traces how, in its homeland, the gentle sakura was...

title: Stocks to Watch: Chevron, JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, Boeing, Mosaic, PagerDuty, PNC Financial Services
content:
Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday’s session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.
Chevron Corp.—Down 4% premarket: Chevron has agreed to buy Anadarko Petroleum Corp. in a cash-and-stock deal valued at roughly $33 billion as the company looks to strengthen its market positions in large shale projects, as well as deepwater and natural gas resource basins. Anadarko Petroleum shares are up 32% premarket.
...

title: Spring Books: Gardening
content: Few remember that in the 1960s and ’70s Central Park was a lawless, derelict, graffiti-covered no-man’s land, shunned by most New Yorkers as being far too dangerous and scary to enter. In her forthright and fascinating “Saving Central Park” (Knopf, 301 pages, $30), Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, founder and spearhead of the Central Park Conservancy, recounts the story of how she, as a recent Wellesley graduate with an advanced degree in urban planning, settled in Manhattan in 1964, fell in love with the city’s “masterpiece of landscape design,” and soon burned with a passion to reclaim it for all New Yorkers. Passages Quote: d...

title: Pollen Counts: The Numbers Behind Spring Sneezing
content:
The classic signs of spring have emerged: Red eyes, runny noses and fits of sneezing.
Nearly 20 million Americans, or about 8% of the population, suffer from seasonal allergies, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.
But many more believe they do.
...

title: ‘Savage Feast’ Review: Self-Discovery at the Family Table
content: Almost three decades after the fall of the Soviet Union, many members of the Russian diaspora—especially those who came of age during the post-Soviet era—are turning a curious and longing eye to the lost flavors of their food heritage. There’s first-generation American Bonnie Morales, born in the Chicago area to Belarusian parents and now based in Portland, Ore.; Ms. Morales’s restaurant, Kachka, and her cookbook of the same name, have brought national attention to creative Russian fare. London-based Olia Hercules’s cookbooks, “Mamushka” and “Kaukasis,” explore the dishes of her ancestral Ukraine and surrounding region;...

title: Lawsuits in U.S. Target a Former Sri Lankan Official
content:
A former defense secretary of Sri Lanka and a possible candidate in that nation’s coming presidential election is facing two separate federal lawsuits in the U.S. alleging he was complicit in torture as well as the death of a journalist.
Gotabaya Rajapaksa, who served in the administration of his brother, former Sri Lankan President Mahinda Rajapaksa, oversaw the final campaigns of that South Asian island nation’s civil war between the government and a splinter group of ethnic Tamils. International observers say that conflict...

title: 2019’s Top Three Trends in Garden Design
content: A RECENT SURVEY of the National Association of Landscape Professionals revealed that the zeitgeist of garden design has little to do with botanical cultivation and everything to do with squeezing additional living space out of our yards. When the association asked 1,000 designers and contractors to predict the most influential landscaping trends for 2019, three emerged: pergolas, a framework or archway which delineates if not encloses an area; unpolished metal finishes, which lend an earthy elegance to structures like walls; and multitasking built-ins that make the most of the puny footprint many of us are working with....

title: Disney Plus Wows Investors, But Can It Beat Netflix?
content:
Investors have been hearing about Disney’s hopes and dreams for streaming since the company started bidding for the assets of 21st Century Fox. On Thursday, they finally got a few details to sink their teeth into—and they appear to be pleased. The stock rallied to a record high, but it still isn’t clear how much share Disney can take from Netflix.
Disney said that its Disney+ streaming service will launch in the U.S. on Nov. 12, for $6.99 a month—half the price of Netflix, the current streaming champ. It will offer programming...

title: Bolsonaro Takes Aim at Brazil’s History
content:
SÃO PAULO—Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has long declared war on the news media. His next target is more ambitious—history.
The right-wing former army captain, who took office in January, has made it his mission to rewrite five centuries of Brazil’s past, from colonialism to contemporary democracy.
He has denied that Portuguese colonizers...

title: Chevron to Buy Anadarko Petroleum in $33 Billion Cash-and-Stock Deal
content:
Chevron Corp. has agreed to buy Anadarko Petroleum Corp. in a $33 billion deal that expands its shale-drilling ambitions and places it just behind Exxon Mobil Corp. as one of the world’s largest publicly traded producers of oil and gas.
The combined company is set to become the leading operator in the heart of America’s fracking boom in West Texas and New Mexico at a time when the U.S. pumps more crude than Saudi Arabia and Russia. The value of Chevron and Anadarko’s U.S. drilling prospects exceeds $100 billion, more than...

title: Ecuador Jilted Assange as It Sought to Build Ties With U.S.
content:
Ecuador’s diplomatic protection of Julian Assange once allowed the small Andean nation’s leftist government to antagonize its U.S. foe and argue that it was defending free speech, while cracking down on the press at home.
But after seven years and a new government, that relationship frayed, as President Lenín Moreno sought to improve Ecuador’s relations with the U.S.
After...

title: How Trump’s Pressure Puts the Fed in a Policy Pickle
content:
The Federal Reserve went from steady interest-rate increases in 2018 to a pause to what traders reckon are better chances of a cut than a hike when it next decides to change short-term borrowing costs. Now President Trump says he would like not only to see rate cuts but also a resumption of the Fed’s bond-buying program that’s been credited with helping propel one of the longest bull markets in history.
Whether or not Mr. Trump’s unusual public pressure has played a role in the central bank’s recent shift, the Fed’s dovish...

title: Chevron Shareholders Had a Different Kind of Green in Mind
content:
Chevron is jumping on a good deal that shareholders don’t need. The California-based supermajor is buying midsize oil and gas producer Anadarko for an enterprise value of $50 billion. By several measures, the deal looks reasonable. If only shareholders in fossil-fuel companies were sold on their spending money for fossil fuels.
Anadarko brings Chevron plenty of crude, to be sure, but also ups its exposure to liquefied natural gas. The deal bolsters Chevron in an area where it already outpaces rival Exxon Mobil: the oil-rich...

title: What Can’t This Bread Do?
content:
WHEN MY MOTHER emigrated from Delhi, India, to Nashua, N.H., in 1980, she didn’t know how to cook. But she could make roti. This flatbread (also known as chapatti) has, after all, been a building block of Indian cuisine for millennia. In her and my dad’s tiny apartment, she would experiment with recipes from cookbooks: corn timbal, minestrone soup, lo mein. Some were Indian, some weren’t. All were served with a side of roti.
The basic recipe consists of wheat flour, water, salt and a smidge of oil, rolled out into a circle...

title: Teaching Girls to Be Great Competitors
content: Young girls today are taught to believe that they can be anything they want to be: “Girl power!” But reaching for the top requires a healthy competitive drive, and new research shows that many girls have trouble managing the stress and emotions that go along with competition. This reluctance to compete can have an impact on girls’ educational choices, career trajectories and eventual earning power, contributing to the historic pay gap between men and women. Fortunately, psychologists say that parents can help girls to become more comfortable with competition—as long as the focus is on the right kind of striving against...

title: One Teenager Killed Himself. Six More Followed.
content:
HERRIMAN, Utah—Eight months to the day after his only son, Chandler, killed himself, Kurt Voutaz was in his kitchen eating lunch.
He and his wife, Catherine, had long since ripped the blood-soaked carpet out of Chandler’s bedroom and cleaned the walls and ceiling. It was warm for February, and they had taken the snow tires off the car. They were hoping winter was over.
Suddenly,...

title: Bristol-Myers Shareholders Approve $74 Billion Deal For Celgene
content:
Bristol-Myers Squibb shareholders on Friday approved the company’s $74 billion acquisition of rival Celgene Corp., looking past an unsuccessful activist campaign to break up the deal.
The deal, first announced Jan. 3, passed with more than 75% of shareholders voting in favor of it. About 24% of shareholders voted against the deal, with less than 1% abstained. A majority of the shares voted were needed for approval. The deal is expected to be completed in the third quarter this year.
...

title: Sydney Brenner Helped Decipher the Genetic Code, Partly by Studying Tiny Worms
content:
His mother wanted him to be a physician. Though he halfheartedly completed medical school in his native South Africa, Sydney Brenner, the son of an immigrant cobbler, had a bigger agenda: unlocking the mysteries of human cells and genetics.
Forsaking medicine, he made his career as a molecular biologist in England, where his work illuminated how genetic information regulates the life and death of individual cells. In 2002, he shared the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with two other scientists for studies of the genetics...

title: Spring Books: Sports
content: The Library of America’s “Great American Sports Page” (LOA, 396 pages, $29.95), edited and with an introduction by John Schulian, gathers selections from nearly 100 years of everyday sports writing, thumped-out, deadline-driven column inches clipped from America’s daily newspapers. The pieces run from the age of the gods, Ring Lardner, Grantland Rice and Heywood Broun, through the palmy days of Red Smith, W.C. Heinz and Joe Palmer down to our own era of sports columnists, of men (and now women) soldiering on against the forces of sports radio, cable television and the internet. In these pages, baseball is the clear winner,...

title: Technology Isn’t a Force for Liberation After All
content:
There was some good news this week for those of us who worry that the human race is descending into a technological dystopia in which our every move is tracked, cataloged and eventually used against us by vast, malevolent forces.
The Journal reported that last July the Metropolitan Transportation Authority—the organization that runs (I use the term loosely) the subways, much of the railway network and the toll bridges and tunnels in New York—launched a pilot scheme to capture the identities of drivers speeding over one of...

title: Surprised on a Daily Basis: Senate GOP’s Bond With Trump Is Fraying
content:
WASHINGTON—Aides were milling around on the Senate floor one day last week when a manila envelope arrived by courier from the White House.
Typically the envelopes contain formal notice of moves that have already been coordinated at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue. Not this time: It said the administration was withdrawing its nomination of Ronald Vitiello for director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
Taken...

title: Spring Books: Children’s Books
content:
April Pulley Sayre captures the explosive glory of springtime in “Bloom Boom!” (Beach Lane, 40 pages, $17.99). In this picture book for children 2-6, she has paired brief lines of text with dramatic photographs of flowers in a variety of natural settings to celebrate the stages of growth and flourishing. “Leaves emerge. Stalks surge. Bloom boom!” we read as the wild lupine ventures out and then stands tall with its purple blossoms. “Colors call. Fragrance flies,” writes Ms. Sayre, her camera taking us right up close to the pink loveliness of crab apple and magnolia: “Welcome, birds and butterflies!”
The...

title: Shazam! A Magic Word With A Pedigree In Exotic Nonsense
content:
The latest comic-book superhero movie to conquer the box office is “Shazam!” Based on a character from DC Comics, the film raked in $158.6 million worldwide on its opening weekend. It tells the story of young Billy Batson, who can transform into an adult superhero (complete with costume) by uttering the magic word—spoiler alert—“Shazam!”
That word might sound simple, but it’s got a complicated history, both inside and outside the comic-book world.
...

title: Children’s Furniture That Will Make Them Feel Grown-Up
content:
CHILDREN’S FURNITURE styles seem to be maturing as quickly as the tots destined to spill juice on them. Here, Adam Carolla—comedian, podcast host and father of two—speculates on the type of kids to whom these five new and precociously chic chairs would most appeal.
Micro Maximalist
In a collaboration with children’s clothing brand Monica + Andy, custom furniture company Interior Define has downsized their popular Gray Collection (above). Mr. Carolla imagines this bold-leafed seat as a match for a progressive, sustainability-minded...

title: Social-Media Movements Helped Drive Out African Leaders
content:
Activists whose street protests precipitated the military overthrow of Sudan’s longtime leader relied on social media, including Facebook, to spread the word, spurring change through platforms that have come under fire for helping spread hate and division.
A loose group of Sudanese professionals and activists that accused President Omar al-Bashir of looting the country during his 30-year reign used Facebook to announce the time and place of their protests and encourage people to attend.
...

title: Fidelity’s Index-Fund Bashing Misses the Mark
content:
Sometimes, what research shows is less telling than what it doesn’t show.
Consider a recent study from Fidelity Investments that has been circulating widely among financial advisers. It indicates that index, or passive, funds—those popular investment baskets that run on autopilot by tracking all the holdings in a market benchmark like the S&P 500 index—may not be as superior as many investors think.
One...

title: Surprise Medical Bills and Informed Consent
content:
It seems to me that the problem of surprise medical bills could be fixed without the heavy hand of government regulation (“Fix for Surprise Medical Charges Gains Support,” U.S. News, April 3). A hospital could institute a rule that any physician who chooses to practice there must agree to the negotiated payment. I know, I know: much too simple.
Susan Dickson
...

title: Trump Targets Sanctuary Cities Amid Stepped Up Immigration Push
content:
WASHINGTON—President Trump revived an idea of relocating detained immigrants to so-called sanctuary cities, signaling he is considering previously discarded options amid his growing frustration over the flow of Central American families seeking asylum at the southern U.S. border.
Mr. Trump’s comments, which also marked a new shot at his political opponents, came after a week in which many top leaders at the Department of Homeland Security were ousted. The president has been working with advisers including Stephen Miller to...

title: Petrobras Shares Hit by Concerns About Government Interference in Pricing
content:
SÃO PAULO—The share price of state-controlled Petróleo Brasileiro SA declined Friday on concern Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro had abandoned a policy announced in January and interfered with the oil company’s pricing policy.
Preferred shares of Petrobras, as the company is commonly known, closed 7.8% lower at 25.83 reais ($6.64) following news reports that the government on Thursday had ordered the suspension of a planned 5.7% price increase for diesel fuel to help truckers.
...

title: Abraaj Founder Accused of Fraud as U.S. Seeks Extradition
content:
Abraaj Group founder Arif Naqvi was arrested in the U.K. after U.S. prosecutors requested his extradition as part of a sprawling criminal case against the architect of what was the largest private-equity firm in emerging markets before it collapsed last year.
Mr. Naqvi, 58, was accused of secretly diverting “at least hundreds of millions of investors’ funds” for personal gain and to help shore up Dubai-based Abraaj’s crumbling finances before it filed for provisional liquidation last June, according to the indictment which...

title: Thanks, Mom and Dad, for Not Oversharing My Life
content:
If Daryl Austin was truly interested in documenting his children’s journeys so they can fondly look back on their apparently joyful, perfectly curated upbringing, he wouldn’t be sharing his photographs on Instagram (“My Kids Will Thank Me For Oversharing Online,” op-ed, April 3). Platforms change, and the digital landscape will likely have completely morphed by the time his kids are interested in revisiting their childhood.
Crediting their future gratitude for his present need to feel validated is shameful. I’m grateful my...

title: Thousands of Sudanese Protest Against Military Takeover
content:
The leader of the defense forces that ousted Sudan’s longtime dictator Omar al-Bashir stepped down on Friday, in a sign of discord among military factions as thousands stayed on the streets calling for a civilian-led transition.
Defense Minister Ahmed Awad Ibn Auf said late Friday he stepped down to preserve the unity of the armed forces. He will be succeeded by another senior military commander, Lt. Gen. Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Burhan, former chief of staff of ground forces under Mr. Bashir.
...

title: Bolsonaro’s Pension Reform Plan Threatened by Brazil Graft Probe
content:
BRASÍLIA—Operation Car Wash, Brazil’s sprawling graft investigation, is imperiling President Jair Bolsonaro’s attempt to fix the country’s insolvent pension system.
Federal prosecutors on Wednesday filed a petition to the Supreme Court revealing that House Speaker Rodrigo Maia is under investigation for allegedly taking bribes in the past from engineering giant Odebrecht SA.
Mr....

title: BlackRock CEO Laurence Fink Takes Pay Cut
content:
The boss of the world’s largest money manager took a pay cut in 2018, a reflection of a tougher year for the industry.
BlackRock Inc. Chief Executive Laurence Fink received $24 million for his performance last year, a 14% decrease from 2017, according to a regulatory filing Friday. The amount includes a $7.75 million cash award, $14.75 million in deferred equity and incentives, as well as a base salary of $1.5 million. In 2017, he earned $27.95 million.
...

title: Executives Must Be the Adults in the Room
content:
Regarding your editorial “Google’s Advisory Board Crash and Burn” (April 6): Google isn’t the only high-tech company to be challenged by a subset of its employees who can’t distinguish between the good guys and the bad. Microsoft faced a similar demand from dissidents earlier this year to cancel a contract with the Defense Department, saying they “refuse to create technology for warfare and oppression.” The technology in question was a device that enhances the views of battlefield terrain for the infantry where 90% of all casualties from hostile action occur.
In...

title: Interview Transcripts Tell Story of Fed Over Past 50 Years
content:
Transcripts of more than 50 interviews with top Federal Reserve officials and staffers offer an inside view of central bank-operations over the past 50 years, including internal debates and pressures from the White House.
Among the documents released Friday are interviews with former Fed leaders Paul Volcker, Alan Greenspan and Janet Yellen as part of an oral history project in advance of the central bank’s centennial in 2013.
The...

title: Chevron-Anadarko Deal Sends Shale Stocks Surging
content:
Shares in some of the biggest shale companies soared on hopes that Chevron Corp.’s $33 billion deal to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp. could start a wave of consolidation in the U.S. oil patch.
Pioneer Natural Resources Co., Concho Resources Inc. and Parsley Energy Inc. shares each surged more than 8% Friday, as investors speculated that bigger players’ long-expected gobbling up of smaller ones could finally be at hand. Meanwhile, a broader index of U.S. oil-and-gas companies was up about 3%, compared with an increase of...

title: A Mythic Moment in Modern Painting
content: In October 1888, on a small wooden panel covered with brilliant, unmixed colors and boldly simplified forms, Paul Sérusier (1864-1927) proposed a radical new philosophy of art. His “Landscape at the Bois d’Amour,” also known as “Le Talisman,” painted en plein air in Pont-Aven, Brittany, under the close direction of the artist Paul Gauguin, sets aside the mimetic approach that earlier artists, including recent Impressionists, had adopted since the Renaissance. Instead it celebrates painting as an autonomous medium of expression that favors the painter’s unique visual perception over an accurate representation of nature....

title: Test-Taking Whiz in College Admissions Scandal Expected to Plead Guilty
content:
BOSTON—A test-taking whiz who is a crucial player in the college-admissions cheating scandal pleaded guilty in federal court here Friday.
Prosecutors say Mark Riddell, 36 years old, helped teens cheat on college-entrance exams by correcting their answers, achieving impressive scores that were then submitted to selective colleges.
Mr. Riddell,...

title: Joe Biden: Being in Touch Without Touching
content:
Regarding Peggy Noonan’s “If Joe Biden Runs, They’ll Tear Him Up” (Declarations, April 6): My aunt wasn’t a hugging person so she let me know right away and I quit hugging her. I can’t tell you how many times a woman has come up to me and given me a hug or how many times female students hugged me at the end of a school year. The fact is that some people are very affectionate and some aren’t, and those who aren’t need to let those who are know it by kindly telling them so.
It’s strange that, during all this talk about Joe...

title: As Brexit Deadline Slips, Nigel Farage Launches New Anti-EU Party
content:
LONDON—Pro-Brexit figurehead Nigel Farage launched a new political party to fight a European election few people thought would happen in Britain and where the winners might never take their seats.
At a summit this week, European Union leaders agreed to postpone Britain’s departure from the bloc until Oct. 31 to make time for Prime Minister Theresa May to push a divorce deal through Parliament. Britain was originally scheduled to leave the EU on March 29.
...

title: California Governor Proposes Fixes to State’s Wildfire Crisis
content:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom on Friday released a suite of proposals for how to confront the soaring wildfire liability costs that pushed PG&E Corp. into bankruptcy and threaten the financial health of the state’s other utilities.
The ideas include creating a California wildfire fund to spread costs from fire-related lawsuits, and modifying a state liability standard that makes utilities responsible for damages arising from fires sparked by their equipment, even if they aren’t found negligent in maintaining it.
...

title: Trooper Deaths and LED Lights That are Too Bright
content:
Regarding the article “Surge in State Troopers Killed by Vehicles” (U.S. News, April 2): While I’m certain that distracted driving is a major factor, another is the escalation of illumination. With LED lighting on more and more vehicles, approaching a public-safety vehicle becomes a blinding experience. The lighting is greatly in excess of what is necessary. And with more and more drivers over the age of 50, you are more likely to temporarily blind drivers at the worst possible moment.
Jon Gersh
...

title: Weaker Dollar Boosts Gold
content:
Gold prices rose Friday, lifted by a weaker dollar.
Gold for June delivery was up 0.2% at $1,295.20 a troy ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The WSJ Dollar Index was down 0.2% at 90.04, boosting gold, which is denominated in the U.S. currency and becomes more affordable to foreign investors when the dollar weakens....

title: Pelosi Solidifies Her Standing With House Democrats
content:
LEESBURG, Va.—In her first three months back as House speaker, Nancy Pelosi has had to contend with tensions between Democratic centrists and liberals, a high-profile battle with President Trump over a government shutdown, and how to handle the issue of potential presidential impeachment.
What she no longer has to deal with, according to a wide range of House Democrats, is doubt within her own ranks as to her suitability for the job. Before November’s elections, it appeared possible the 79-year-old California Democrat would...

title: Crypto Fund Polychain’s Assets Drop 40% From $1 Billion Mark
content:
Olaf Carlson-Wee’s Polychain Capital touted itself as being a billion-dollar crypto hedge fund last year.
It can no longer lay claim to that distinction.
The firm’s assets under management dropped to $591.5 million as of the end of 2018, according to regulatory filings Polychain made in March.
...

title: Former Obama Counsel Pleads Not Guilty to Lying to Justice Department
content:
WASHINGTON—Former Obama White House counsel Greg Craig pleaded not guilty to charges of lying to the Justice Department about his work on behalf of foreign governments.
In an appearance Friday in federal court, Mr. Craig’s attorneys entered a plea of not guilty on two false-statement charges stemming from work he and his former law firm did on behalf of the Ukrainian government.
Mr....

title: U.S. Charges Drug Maker Indivior With Organizing Multibillion-Dollar Fraud
content:
Federal prosecutors charged a U.K. pharmaceutical company with organizing a multibillion-dollar fraud to drive up sales of Suboxone Film, an opioid-addiction treatment.
As part of an indictment filed Tuesday in Virginia, the Justice Department said Indivior PLC set up a telephone and online program intended to connect callers with doctors that Indivior knew were prescribing Suboxone or opioids in a “careless and clinically unwarranted manner.”
...

title: Mount Sinai Increases Effort to Cut Medical-Student Debt
content:
New York City’s Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai announced Wednesday that it will expand scholarships in a bid to lower the total debt of its medical students, a move that follows other recent debt-relief efforts at New York medical schools.
The plan, called the Enhanced Scholarship Initiative, will enable students to graduate with no more than $75,000 in debt, or about $18,750 a year in institutional and federal loans.
School...

title: The CEO Of CVS Is Betting On A Proven Answer To Fight Rising Drug Pric
content: CVS CEO Larry J. Merlo sits with Jack Hough, Barron's Associate Editor, to unravel the many reasons why pharmaceutical prices are at an all-time high and how to make prescription drugs more accessible.

title: A Private Jet May Break the Sound Barrier
content:
Reno, Nev.
Operating out of rental offices near a cluster of gaudy casinos is a quiet little company that’s making the most audacious bet in contemporary aviation. Aerion, founded only 15 years ago, is poised to build the world’s first civilian supersonic aircraft since the Concorde—whose first flight took place 50 years ago last month.
Although...

title: Of Hominins and the Stars
content:
You no doubt have read, several thousand times, that we live in depressing times with diminished prospects thanks to mankind’s many depredations against earth and science. Well, cheer up. Many talented human beings this week demonstrated again that we are creative and curious creatures who dare to dream and discover. Behold the excavation of fossils belonging to a previously unknown human species and the first photograph of a black hole.
Scientists on Wednesday reported they had unearthed fossilized teeth and bones of a cousin...

title: ‘The Parisian’ Review: A Franco-Palestinian Education
content:
When a young hero sets out on a journey, the reader settles in for a story of the ample, meandering kind. Hans Castorp trundles upward to the Magic Mountain, Jim Hawkins sails off to Treasure Island, and we happily tag along (pleased to recall, perhaps, that it was at Davos, Thomas Mann’s inspiration for his mountain, that Robert Louis Stevenson completed his pirate adventure). A similar charm pervades “The Parisian,” the assured and captivating first novel by British-Palestinian writer Isabella Hammad.
Rich in romantic stratagems—an...

title: ‘Working’ Review: ‘Just Remember: Turn Every Page’
content:
Embarking on his biography of Lyndon Johnson in the mid-1970s, Robert Caro went to the pharaonic LBJ library and museum in Austin, Texas. He asked where the 36th president’s papers were kept and was directed to a great marble staircase.
“At its top was a glass wall four stories high,” he writes in “Working.” “Behind the glass, on each of the four stories, were rows of tall red boxes—175 rows across, each row six boxes high. . . . All I could see from the bottom of the stairs were those boxes, but as I climbed the stairs, there...

title: ‘The Masters’ Review: What Makes a Great Course Great
content:
The Masters, which started Thursday, is almost everybody’s favorite golf tournament. Timing is part of it. It’s the first of the four men’s majors to be played each year, and by April even non-golfers are ready to embrace the visual splendor of the Augusta National Golf Club course in Georgia, azaleas and dogwoods in full bloom. The Masters is also the only major played on the same course each year. Over decades of watching the Masters, fans get to know each splendid hole of the course as well as they know the swales and bowers of their local park or, indeed, their own backyard.
Augusta’s...

title: At Disney, Bob Iger’s Successor Will Inherit His Big Streaming Bet
content:
LOS ANGELES—Walt Disney Co. Chief Executive Bob Iger won high marks from investors after showcasing the company’s new streaming-video service on Thursday.
Before too long, another executive will be seeing that strategy through.
Mr. Iger said he plans to leave when his contract expires in 2021. Disney’s board is currently engaged in finding...

title: EU Prepares Tariffs Against U.S. Amid WTO Battle
content:
BRUSSELS—The European Union is preparing tariffs on $12 billion of U.S. products over subsidies to Boeing Co., raising the stakes on the Trump administration’s plan for punishing the EU’s support to rival plane maker Airbus SE.
Europe’s move came after a U.S. said on Monday it intended to impose tariffs on $11.2 billion of imports from the EU. Brussels’s swift response highlights its resolve to go blow-for-blow with Washington over the matter.
...
